definitions: most important or having the greatest significance among other things
occurring first in time or sequence before others of the same type
forming an essential foundation or basis from which everything else develops
examples: The primary goal is to improve customer satisfaction
Safety is our primary concern when designing new products
We studied primary sources from the colonial period
Children attend primary school before moving to secondary education
Understanding primary colors helps artists mix any shade they need
These primary principles guide all our business decisions

definitions: unusual or surprising in a way that is unsettling or hard to understand
not previously known, seen, or encountered; unfamiliar or alien to one's experience
not feeling physically right or comfortable; experiencing unusual sensations
examples: That's a strange noise coming from the engine
She had strange dreams about flying through space
Everything felt strange in the new country at first
The strange customs of the tribe fascinated the anthropologist
I've been feeling strange since eating that seafood
He looked strange and pale after the long flight

definitions: engaging in physical movement or showing energetic participation in activities
currently functioning, operating, or producing effects in the present time
requiring or characterized by physical or mental participation rather than passive observation
examples: She stays active by swimming three times a week
The children are very active after their afternoon nap
The volcano has been active for the past month
Keep your subscription active to continue receiving updates
Active learning methods help students retain information better
This game requires active involvement from all players

definitions: extending or moving from one place to another by the shortest way without changing direction
honest and straightforward in manner or speech without attempting to deceive or evade
with nothing or no one in between; involving only the parties concerned
examples: Take the direct route to avoid traffic delays
The direct flight to London saves three hours
She gave a direct answer to the difficult question
His direct approach sometimes offends sensitive people
Buy direct from the manufacturer for better prices
The CEO prefers direct communication with all employees

definitions: not able to occur, exist, or be done under any circumstances
extremely difficult or inconvenient to the point of seeming unreasonable
examples: It's impossible to travel faster than light
Finding a parking spot here is virtually impossible
The deadline is impossible to meet with current resources
She sets impossible standards for herself and others

definitions: concerned with the principles of right and wrong behavior and the goodness or badness of human character
conforming to accepted standards of good behavior and showing high principles
based on mental or emotional factors rather than physical or practical ones
examples: The moral implications of genetic engineering are widely debated
Every decision we make has moral consequences to consider
She's a moral person who always tries to help others
The story teaches moral lessons about honesty and kindness
The team needs moral support after their recent losses
His moral victory meant more than any financial reward

definitions: relating to education and scholarship, especially at college or university level
not having practical relevance or application; purely theoretical or hypothetical in nature
showing qualities associated with serious study and scholarship; intellectual and learned
examples: Her academic achievements earned her multiple scholarship offers
The academic year begins in September for most universities
The debate became purely academic when funding was withdrawn
That's an academic question since we can't change the past
He writes in an academic style unsuitable for general readers
The journal publishes academic research on climate change

definitions: based on or characterized by the methods and principles of science
done in a systematic way using careful observation and experimentation
examples: Scientific evidence supports the theory of evolution
The research follows strict scientific protocols and standards
She takes a scientific approach to solving business problems
Their scientific method of training produces consistent results

definitions: belonging to or coming from the continent of Africa
relating to Africa or its peoples, languages, or cultures
examples: African elephants are larger than their Asian cousins
She studied African history at the university
The museum features African art from various regions
African music has influenced many modern genres worldwide

definitions: sexually or romantically attracted to people of one's own sex
bright, colorful, and cheerful in appearance or manner
light-hearted and carefree; showing no concern for serious matters
examples: The city has a vibrant gay community and culture
Gay marriage is now legal in many countries worldwide
The room was decorated with gay ribbons and balloons
Her gay laughter filled the entire house with joy
In his gay youth, he traveled the world without worry
They spent gay hours dancing and singing together

definitions: suitable or proper in the circumstances; fitting for a particular purpose, occasion, or place
examples: Please wear appropriate clothing for the formal dinner
It's not appropriate to use your phone during meetings

definitions: easily perceived or understood; clear, self-evident, or apparent to the mind or senses
examples: The answer is obvious once you understand the pattern
It was obvious that she hadn't slept well last night

definitions: having a distance larger than usual from side to side; wide
covering a large number and wide scope of subjects or topics
general and lacking detail or precision; not specific or particular
examples: The river grows broad as it nears the ocean
He has broad shoulders from years of swimming
She has broad knowledge of European history and culture
The new law will have broad implications for businesses
They reached a broad agreement on the main issues
The report paints a broad picture of economic trends

definitions: free from error; in accordance with fact or truth; accurate
conforming to accepted social standards; proper in behavior or etiquette
examples: Please check that all the answers are correct
The correct spelling is 'receive,' not 'recieve'
It's not correct to interrupt when someone is speaking
She always uses the correct fork at formal dinners

definitions: joined to another person in matrimony; having a husband or wife
closely combined or linked together in a way that seems permanent
examples: They've been happily married for twenty-five years
Married couples can file their taxes jointly
She's married to her work and rarely takes vacations
The artist is married to traditional techniques

definitions: of or concerning history or past events; belonging to the past
based on or concerned with events in history rather than legend or fiction
examples: The historical records show population growth over centuries
This building has great historical significance for our town
The movie takes some liberties with historical accuracy
Historical fiction must balance fact with creative storytelling

definitions: being the only one of its kind; unlike anything else in existence
particularly remarkable, special, or unusual in character or quality
examples: Each snowflake has a unique crystalline structure
Your fingerprints are unique and can't be duplicated
She has a unique talent for making people laugh
The restaurant offers a unique dining experience

definitions: well known from long or close association; easily recognized or remembered
relaxed and informal in manner or behavior; inappropriately intimate or presumptuous
examples: The melody sounds familiar but I can't name it
These streets are familiar from my childhood years
Don't be too familiar with your new colleagues yet
His familiar tone annoyed the senior executives

definitions: belonging to or coming from France or its people
relating to France, its people, language, or culture
examples: French wine is famous throughout the world
She ordered french fries with her burger
He's studying French literature at the Sorbonne
French cuisine emphasizes fresh ingredients and technique

definitions: feeling or showing sorrow; unhappy or experiencing grief
causing sorrow or a feeling of loss or disappointment
inadequate, pathetic, or deserving of contempt or pity
examples: She felt sad when her best friend moved away
The sad expression on his face revealed his disappointment
It's sad to see the old theater being demolished
The sad news spread quickly through the small town
That's a sad excuse for not completing your work
The team's sad performance disappointed their loyal fans

definitions: known about by many people; having fame or public recognition for achievements
examples: The famous actor signed autographs for waiting fans
Paris is famous for its art museums and cafes

definitions: magnificent and imposing in appearance, size, or style; impressive and ambitious
ambitious or magnificent in scale, scope, or extent of conception
of the highest rank, status, or importance; principal or chief
examples: The grand staircase dominated the mansion's entrance hall
They made a grand entrance at the charity gala
She has grand plans to expand her business globally
The grand vision for the city includes new parks
He holds the grand title of Chief Executive Officer
The grand prize includes a luxury vacation package

definitions: having, bringing, or resulting from good luck or fortune
producing or resulting in good fortune by chance rather than design
examples: She was lucky to find a parking space downtown
The lucky winner received a million dollar prize
Seven is considered a lucky number in many cultures
He always wears his lucky socks to important games

definitions: feeling deep pleasure or satisfaction from one's achievements, qualities, or possessions
having or showing an excessively high opinion of oneself or one's importance
impressive, grand, or splendid in appearance or bearing
examples: Parents were proud of their children's academic achievements
She's proud to represent her country at the Olympics
He's too proud to admit when he's made mistakes
Her proud nature prevents her from accepting help
The proud oak tree has stood for two hundred years
The proud ship sailed majestically into the harbor

definitions: feeling or showing strong annoyance, displeasure, or hostility
threatening or suggesting violence or danger; dark and stormy
examples: She was angry about the unfair treatment she received
The angry customer demanded to speak with the manager
Angry clouds gathered on the horizon before the storm
The angry sea tossed the small boat dangerously

definitions: associated with the place or circumstances of a person's birth
belonging to a person or thing by nature; inherent rather than acquired
relating to the original inhabitants of a place before colonization
examples: She returned to her native country after twenty years
English is not his native language but he speaks fluently
The koala is native to Australia and nowhere else
These plants are native to tropical rainforest environments
Native peoples have lived on this land for thousands of years
The museum displays native art from various tribes

definitions: highest in rank, authority, or power; having ultimate control
greatest in degree, quality, or importance; surpassing all others
examples: The supreme court makes final decisions on constitutional matters
She holds supreme authority over all company operations
This dish represents the supreme achievement of French cooking
He showed supreme confidence during the championship match

definitions: becoming greater in size, amount, or degree over a period of time
undergoing development or maturation; progressing toward adulthood or completion
examples: The growing population puts pressure on city services
There's growing concern about climate change effects
Children have different nutritional needs during growing years
The growing season for crops varies by region

definitions: most important or primary among several things of the same type
highest in rank or authority; principal leader of a group or organization
examples: The chief reason for the delay was bad weather
Safety is our chief concern in this operation
She was appointed chief of the medical department
The chief executive officer announced record profits

definitions: extremely bad or serious; of very poor quality or condition
causing or likely to cause terror; extremely frightening or dreadful
extreme in degree or extent; used for emphasis of negative qualities
examples: The food at that restaurant was absolutely terrible
She's had a terrible day with everything going wrong
The terrible storm destroyed homes along the coast
They heard terrible screams coming from the forest
He has a terrible habit of interrupting people
The heat during summer here is just terrible

definitions: consisting of many different and connected parts that form an intricate whole
not easy to analyze or understand; complicated and intricate in nature
examples: The human brain is an incredibly complex organ
Modern cars have complex electronic systems
The complex problem required months of careful analysis
Her complex personality makes her fascinating but unpredictable

definitions: moving or operating at a low speed; not quick or fast
lasting or taking a long time to complete or occur
not quick to understand, think, or learn; mentally dull
examples: Traffic moves slow during the morning rush hour
The slow train stops at every small station
Recovery from the surgery will be a slow process
Business has been slow since the holidays ended
He's a bit slow when it comes to mathematics
Don't be slow to recognize great opportunities

definitions: easy to mold, cut, compress, or fold; not hard or stiff
gentle, mild, or sympathetic in manner, action, or effect
not bright, glaring, or loud; pleasantly subdued or muted
examples: The baby's skin feels incredibly soft and smooth
Choose soft fabrics for comfortable summer clothing
She spoke in a soft voice to calm the child
He has a soft spot for stray animals
The room was lit with soft candlelight
Soft music played in the background during dinner

definitions: relating to a large company or group of companies acting as a single entity
belonging to or shared by members of a group collectively
examples: The corporate headquarters moved to a larger building
She climbed the corporate ladder to become CEO
They must consider corporate responsibility to the community
The team worked to build a strong corporate culture

definitions: low in price compared to similar items or to usual cost
of poor quality or little value because of low cost
unwilling to spend money; miserly or stingy in financial matters
examples: These shoes were cheap but they're quite comfortable
It's cheaper to buy groceries in bulk quantities
The cheap furniture broke after only six months
Don't buy cheap tools that won't last long
He's too cheap to leave a decent tip
She's cheap when it comes to buying gifts

definitions: of or denoting the sex that produces gametes, especially spermatozoa
relating to or characteristic of men or boys; masculine
examples: Male lions have distinctive manes around their necks
The study examined differences between male and female brains
Traditional male roles in society are changing rapidly
The club was previously open to male members only

definitions: relating to a person's emotions or the expression of feelings
showing strong feelings or being easily affected by feelings; not rational
designed to arouse or appeal to emotions rather than logic or reason
examples: Emotional intelligence helps people work well together
The therapy addresses both physical and emotional healing
She became emotional when talking about her childhood
He's too emotional to make objective business decisions
The lawyer made an emotional appeal to the jury
The advertisement uses emotional imagery to sell products

definitions: used to express anger, annoyance, contempt, or surprise; vulgar intensifier
used as an intensive to emphasize something, often expressing frustration
examples: This fucking computer keeps crashing every hour
I can't find my fucking keys anywhere
It's fucking cold outside today
That was a fucking amazing performance

definitions: costing a lot of money; having a high price compared to similar items
examples: That restaurant is too expensive for everyday dining
Expensive cars require costly maintenance and insurance

definitions: actively engaged in work or other activity; having much to do
full of activity, movement, or things happening; crowded with events
excessively detailed or decorated in a way that seems cluttered
examples: She's too busy to meet until next week
The busy executive scheduled meetings back to back
The busy shopping mall was packed with holiday shoppers
It's a busy intersection with constant traffic
The wallpaper design is too busy for a small room
Her busy patterns clash with the simple furniture

definitions: in need of sleep or rest; feeling fatigue or exhaustion
bored with or no longer interested in something from overexposure
examples: The tired children fell asleep in the car
She was tired after working a twelve-hour shift
I'm tired of eating the same lunch every day
People are tired of empty political promises

definitions: joined together politically, socially, or for a common purpose
acting together in agreement or harmony for a shared goal
examples: The united nations works to maintain world peace
They formed a united front against the proposal
The team was united in their determination to win
A united effort is needed to solve this crisis

definitions: relating to the process of teaching or to the field of education
providing knowledge, instruction, or information that teaches or informs
examples: The educational system needs reform to meet modern needs
She works for an educational publishing company
The museum offers educational programs for children
Television can be educational when used properly

definitions: containing nothing; not filled or occupied with anything
having no meaning, value, or purpose; lacking substance or sincerity
containing no people; deserted or uninhabited
examples: The empty bottle needs to be recycled
Her purse was empty except for some loose change
His promises turned out to be empty words
She felt empty after achieving her lifelong goal
The empty streets were eerie late at night
They moved into the empty apartment next door

definitions: providing physical ease and relaxation; pleasant to use, wear, or experience
free from stress, worry, or anxiety; feeling at ease mentally
having enough money to live well without financial worry
examples: These shoes are comfortable enough for all-day wear
The comfortable chair helped ease his back pain
She feels comfortable speaking in front of large audiences
I'm not comfortable with this risky business plan
They live a comfortable life in the suburbs
His comfortable income allows frequent travel

definitions: able to be used for a practical purpose or in helpful ways
producing good results or being helpful in achieving something
examples: This tool is useful for many household repairs
Keep useful phone numbers in your emergency kit
Your advice was extremely useful in solving the problem
Learning a second language is useful for career advancement

definitions: using or relating to computer technology and electronic data storage
relating to or using the fingers or toes
examples: Digital cameras have replaced traditional film photography
The company is undergoing a digital transformation
The doctor performed a digital examination
Digital dexterity is important for playing piano

definitions: holding traditional values and being averse to change or innovation
moderate, cautious, or purposely low in estimate to avoid risk
favoring free enterprise, private ownership, and traditional social values
examples: His conservative approach to investing avoids risky ventures
The conservative community resisted the proposed changes
The engineer gave a conservative estimate for project completion
It's better to be conservative with your budget projections
Conservative politicians oppose expanding government programs
She votes conservative on most economic issues

definitions: of great or more than average height, especially relative to width
difficult to believe or exaggerated; unreasonable or excessive in demands
examples: The tall building dominates the city skyline
Basketball players are typically tall and athletic
That's a tall tale if I ever heard one
Meeting that deadline is a tall order

definitions: having life; not dead or inanimate; alive and living
happening or being broadcast at the present moment, not recorded
connected to electrical power and able to cause shock; charged with electricity
examples: Live plants need water and sunlight to survive
The market sells live lobsters in seawater tanks
We're watching a live broadcast from the Olympics
The band will perform live at the festival tonight
Don't touch that wire - it might be live
Always assume electrical cables are live until proven otherwise
